reviewText: The Land Before Time is a wonderful movie about a group of five young dinosaurs looking for the Great Valley, the only source of food and water left in their world. Balancing humourous, dramatic, and scary scenes in equal measure, it's an excellent film, particularly for the young.The animation in this movie is excellent. The adult dinosaurs can be a bit awkward looking at times, but the main characters are always exquisite, and there's one scene in particular where a group of flying dinos fight over a berry that's brilliance.It's a great movie for kids, and adults will like it too. The characters are well developed, the story moves along, and it teaches some good lessons to children. Highly recommended.

reviewText: Nostalgia may play a big role in my personal connection with many of these early 90's animated films, but I don't think many people would balk at the staying power and soft emotional heft of `The Land Before Time'.  Marred slightly by the onslaught of inferior sequels (admittedly, I have not seen them all), `The Land Before Time' is an original and moving story of friendship and survival that blossoms gradually in a film that relies on true emotional connection and subtle plot development.  The film has a purposefully restrained pacing which outlines the perils and adventures that abound in a relaxed light, allowing the audience to really follow and become a part of the story.`The Land Before Time' tells the story of young orphaned Littlefoot, a brontosaurus who takes on a journey to find the Great Valley, a place filled with vegetation where the dinosaurs can live in peace and harmony.  He is accompanied by friends of varied species who are attempting to reconnect with their families in the Valley.  Expressing the power of friendship and the life lesson that friends can come in all shapes and sizes (and loyalty is something that cannot be taken for granted), this film is a beautifully well rounded film that one cannot help but be affected by.Yes, this brings back so many childhood memories, and it is something that still touches my heart (that finale always brings a tear to my eyes).  With the barrage of modern animated fare, sometimes it's nice to revisit the classics, and despite only being twenty years old, `The Land Before Time' is a classic from my youth and one that I'm proud to adore and introduce to my children.

reviewText: The Land Before Time was one of my favorite childhood movies. To this day I still love this movie. Just like alot of other early Don Bluth films it was darker than most children films of its time and had many intense moments. Compared to Secret of NIHM its a little more child friendly, but still mature in many aspects. It makes me wonder why they started turning it into a musical series when the first one had no singing at all. Don't get me wrong I loved some of the sequals, but after I think the 4 or 5 it just got ridiculus. Well anyway for one you have one of the saddest moments ever in a kids film at the beginning of the movie. I tell you till this day that scene pulls at my heart strings. It was just tragic and brutal. Then you have 5 young dinosaurs in a world full of danger and destruction, search for a safe place that may or may not exist, but its the only hope that keeps them going. Plus they must deal with living with each other which isn't always easy to do. I'm not sure about the DVD, but the VHS of this was great. The colors and animation was just perfect and I hope the DVD is just as perfect. You care about every character in this movie and wish for them to pull through. I must confess the ending also had me in tears for reasons I can't explain. The Land Before Time is a beautiful and very underrated film. I recommend it to everyone. I hope in the future they start making dark animated kids films again.

reviewText: I absolutely LOVED dinosaurs as a kid. I was absolutely fascinated with them. So when this movie first came out I completely wore out the VHS and eventually had to replace it. Its such an endearing and heartwarming film about perseverance and learning to accept what cannot be changed. It covers loss and regret but shows the characters willingness to forge ahead with the belief that there IS good ahead of them. It is truly inspiring and although as a child I did not understand everything. I did take away from this that I should never give up and keep going just like these guys did. Today I am still that person and I truly believe the values this movie tries to teach us is something every child should take into their lives as not only entertainment but as a valuable life lesson-even if they are still too young to understand it. When they are older they will remember :)
summary: classic should be on every kids shelf

reviewText: I remember watching LBT when I was a kid; we had a bunch of rewritable VHS tapes with 2-3 movies recorded on each of them; I think the Land Before Time was recorded on the same tape as the Great Mouse Detective and Robin Hood. I haven't seen this movie since I was like eight years old, and I was SO EXCITED when this showed up in the mail. I'm very proud to say it's as good as it was back then, hasn't lost any of its appeal whatsoever. If anything, it may have gotten better -- in fact I know it did. The visual clarity was excellent; I remember on our old VHS copy I could barely see anything that happened in the opening sequence because it was so dark, but even though the color palette remains dark in the updated edition, you can still make out the little critters swimming around underwater.This is one of those timeless movies I'll never get tired of, and I'll definitely hang onto so my kids, nieces/nephews, etc. can see it in the future. Everyone deserves a feel-good movie like this.

reviewText: Cute movie. Really a kids movie, but fun. Not profound or anything, or even particularly accurate scientifically, but good fun. I was going to say "good clean fun," but there is an incident in the tar pits . . .Littlefoot is a long-neck, Cera is a three-horn, Ducky is a big mouth, Petrie is a pterodactyl and Spike is a stegosaurus. They are all baby dinosaurs that got separated from their families when an earthquake hit. Great herds were on there way to the Great Valley when the earthquake happened, as the land was changing and green food was scarce. They paused only long enough to hatch their babies.Littlefoot's mother died saving him from a Sharp Tooth (Tyrannosaurus Rex), but tells him to follow the big circle in the sky every day (i.e., go west, young dinosaur) past the mountain that looks like a long-neck and the mountains that are on fire.Cera (pronounced "Sarah") was told by her father that three-horns never have anything to do with long-necks, and so she's determined to go her own way. But there are plenty of dangers along the way, and she eventually realizes that she needs to stick with the others. The five all have different voices, manner of speaking, personalities. You can get to see them as individuals partly because of that and partly because there is only one of each species. That is, they look vastly different.Yes, of course they eventually find the Great Valley, and their families. Littlefoot finds his grandparents, since his mother is dead; Cera finds her father, and the rest find their mothers. And yes, it's a lovely valley with plenty of food for all. Probably the central valley of California, since they came by way of La Brea.I give it three stars, mostly because I don't have any children. Otherwise I'd probably give it four.

reviewText: My 5-year-old daughter loves dinosaurs.  She has learned their names, and it's not uncommon to hear her talk about what the diplodocus or dinonychus in her collection is doing, usually using those names (and those like them) in her play.Part of that is thanks to this film and its sequels.  This Spielberg-produced animated film introduces us to the characters, a mixed bag of young vegetarian dinos and their search for "The Great Valley," a place where "sharptooth" dinosaurs won't hunt them; a place where vegetation for their kind is plentiful.The whole series is certainly recommended, due to its quality and its execution.  Children can certainly identify with the varied personalities of the friends; the curious Littlefoot, the headstrong Cera, the timid Ducky, the less eloquent Petrie, and the mellow but large Spike.  The films teach the value of friendship, accepting each other's differences, working together, and respecting your elders while still testing what they have to say.All of that is a difficult tightrope to walk, and those in charge do it consistently well throughout the series.  A new edition is apparently issued near the beginning of each Christmas season (imagine that) so if your little one is approaching preschool age you should let them view this one to see if it's a series they'll enjoy.....and if it's one you'll approve of as much as we do at our house.  There are some fairly intense scenes in each film, but only the most fearful little ones will have a problem with them.
summary: Warning:  Children will get hooked---and that's good!

reviewText: I was 6 or 7 when this film came out, and I always watched it with enthusiasm. I loved it when I saw it when 7 (and esp. the end theme song, sung by Diana Ross). I cried during it, laughed, felt happy, felt sad. I disagree with a previous review given, but I also understand that it does have it's share of so called "violence," but when I was seven, it hardly frightened me anymore than a scene from "Fantasia" would have (think of that "Night on Bald Mountain" scene with all those devilish creatures, now that's SCARY!). If you implement in your child's mind that it should be considered violent, then the child will set themself up for that, and in all honestly, I think it's up to the child in my respects. If the child shuns it, then switch it off; if the child is unaffected, leave it on.But anyway, I love this movie, the soundtrack, and the thoughtfullness of each character and how each grew a little along their journey.
summary: Was worth the watch for me

reviewText: Really, I lost count with how many sequels they have made for The Land Before Time. I've seen only Parts 2 and 3 when I was a kid and I thought they were okay, but now I still prefer the classic original. This is what should be seen by the kids of this generation. This is the one that's filled with a deeper meaning, and is also the one that has one of the most heartbreaking moments in animated cinema history. I'm sure it affected our childhoods in many ways. To me, it is a constant reminder that we don't make animated films like we did back then. I mean, look at "Cars" and "Barnyard." What kind of animated films are THOSE?! But hey, at least we still have the classics in our collection. This one by Don Bluth is one of the greater ones. This story of cooperation, death, home, family, and friendship is still effective even today. I would never even think of forgetting this film. By the way, James Horner's score is terrific. It's definitely one of his finest.Grade: A

reviewText: First of all, the previous reviewer is mistaken, this is NOT a Disney movie but a Don Bluth movie (the one who also made An American Tail).  This is a great movie, like An American Tail, and has a great score composed by James Horner and played by the London Symphony Orchestra (with the King's College Choir).  The animation is pretty decent, some of the scenes (like the one near the end where Spike and Ducky slide across a shallow pool of water) are very nice.  The story is pretty basic, but enjoyable for kids and adults (I saw this as a teen in the theaters).  The characters are mostly very cute and charming, especially Ducky and Petri.And YET, this DVD sucks really bad and no one should buy it.  This DVD is NOT widescreen or anamorphic at all.  It's pretty shameful when EVEN Disney is making their DVDs widescreen.  Furthermore, there are absolutely NO extras on this DVD.  I would have especially appreciated to have trailers, tv spots, audio commentary by Bluth (or others), making of feature, etc.  At the very least, widescreen and a trailer.  Yes, this is a children's movie, but that doesn't mean it has to be fullscreen!  It doesn't take much to put in both full and widescreen versions either.  The same goes for "The Secret Of NIMH," another Bluth film given the fullscreen treatment.BOYCOTT THIS ANNOYING DVD AND DEMAND THAT THEY RELEASE A WIDESCREEN COLLECTOR'S EDITION OF THIS REALLY GREAT MOVIE!!You'll be happy you did!

reviewText: Our 3 year old first became interested in the Land Before Time series when she saw one of them on a cable channel.  Luckily we had recorded it on our TIVO unit because she watches it a least a few times each week.  We recently bought this DVD of the first movie in this series.  She loves it!  The animation and soundtrack are very good.  Although there are some scenes where a T-Rex attacks, it is not too violent or scary, even for young toddlers.  The story itself has a positive message and the characters are very appealing to youngsters (and adults).I only have two complaints about this movie.  First, this is the first DVD I've seen that did not come in a widescreen verson. The picture is cropped to fit a standard TV.  Had I known that, I probably would have bought the VHS edition, which is cheaper. Secondly, some of the later movies in the series have musical scenes where the dinosaurs sing songs.  Most of these songs are actually quite catchy. Our daughter likes these parts.  This episode does not have any songs other than the instrumental soundtrackIf you have children that like feature length cartoons, I think that they will enjoy this movie and the others in the series.

reviewText: ***This review may contain spoilers***I won't repeat the plot, since many preceding reviews have satisfyingly seen to that.  I will agree with those who feel that "The Land Before Time" (hereafter TLBT) is an emotionally rousing, exciting, harrowing, life-affirming prehistoric dinosaur fable espousing the strength of brotherhood, friendship, perseverence, and even spirituality.  You will encounter feisty, lively, contentious, but endearing characters, a frequently hellish environment, titanic natural disasters, a legendary antagonist (i.e. a demonic-looking sharptooth), a mother's heroic death, and even courage and guidance from "above" as our five dinosaur juvenile protagonists seek their leafy, edenic valley.  TLBT is ambitious, rip-roaring, a tad overwrought and cloying, but ultimately a great instructive story for children AND adults.The only real issue with TLBT is the old "Herbivores Good, Carnivores Bad" fallacy.  Perhaps it's unavoidable, since any cinematic animal fable, Disney or Dreamworks or Pixar or otherwise, needs a villain for drama and moral counterpoint.  And of course, a colossal, nimble, ferocious, and determined sharp-toothed T-Rex certainly fits the bill.  Hey, if you're an adult, you suspend disbelief and go with it.  I just hope that parents that watch TLBT with their children explain to them at some point that the T-Rex is not chasing Littlefoot the apatosaurus, Cera the triceratops, Ducky the hadrosaurus, Petrie the pterosaur, and Spike the stegosaurus just to be a mean bully.  To T-Rex, they are just food and they have to eat meat to survive.  Conversely, herbivores are not always good and gentle.  I actually appreciated how TLBT gave us a herbivore like Cera, who can be bossy, obstinate, opinionated, and even cruel (takes after her old man a little bit).  She counterbalances some of the gentler characters.I know, TLBT is not supposed to be naturalistic.  If you wanted to be a petty spoilsport, you could single out some improbabilities (e.g. dinosaurs don't have prehensile tails, pterodactyls eat fish, not berries).  But at the same time, after enjoying TLBT with the kids, you should take the time to expand their curiosity about dinosaurs by explaining more about their true natures, especially as they get older. Herbivores/carnivores are not good/bad, but just do what they do.
summary: Magnificent Dinosaur Trek Fable - Just Remember that Carnivores Aren't Evil

reviewText: This is one of those films that I expected to enjoy much less than many of my family's Disney favorites.  As it turned out, both my children and my wife and I like the movie immensely.The touching story of Little Foot, the last remaining member of his family of Brontosauruses (Brontosauri?), is a great adventure as well.  He joins up with younger members of other dinosaur families as they all journey to the Great Valley in search of food.Along the way they encounter hunger, thirst, earthquakes, and, not least of all, the dreaded Sharptooth.  The feel of the dinosaur age is well presented and the characters are cute without being saccharine (and they don't sing!).The lesson that friends can be friends even though they don't look like you or act just like you is a nice one for kids to see.  The idea that working together is important for reaching a goal is also a valuable one.Having owned a VHS copy of the movie, I was anxious to see the DVD.  The result on this particular version is very dissappointing.First, the version is full-screen with no wide-screen option. This seems to be a minor problem since most of the action seems to take place center screen.  It would have been nice to have the option for widescreen, however.Secondly, the color and brightness varies widely from scene to scene (and, more jarringly, sometimes within a scene).  The opening scene, which starts underwater, is actually darker and less sharp than on the VHS version.  In several quiet, close-up scenes the picture will be perfectly exposed and then the picture will shift to a darker look and then back.  Very annoying.  Various nicks and scratches appear throughout the film - it appears that no effort was made to clean up the video master at all.There were also no extras on the disc at all, and at the price of this DVD, you would expect a little more than just the movie and chapter selections. Disney issued their first few DVDs with little problems like this: no widescreen option, varying degrees of video quality, etc.  They however, have moved to a more consistent product over the last six months.  Hopefully, movies like The Land Before Time will be given better treatment in the future.  This one in particular deserves better than it got.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Even though I know this is an older animated feature, I was frankly shocked how poor the animation looked.  It looked like it would have been decent animation, definitely without the detail of some movies, but it was so grainy and not crisp at all-- so I blame the DVD, because I've seen other Bluth films with animation that blew me away.  So this movie's animation looks much older than it is with all the graininess.  I should have listened to others' reviews that said this was a very poor quality release of a film they love.  It was also dull because of so much brown, orange and yellow due to the land they traveled.  Not very appealing to the eye.But the story is more important than the look, and I found that heavy.  They tried to lighten it up, but really, it was a downer.  There was a violent scene early on in the film, and the mom died.  How sad for her son to see this and have to travel on his own until he met some young friends.  It was sad and not uplifting even when they finally reached their goal in the end after such a long journey.  I know the lesson is perseverance, but  I'd prefer action mixed in with some more fun, too.Too dull to show my kids if it were up to me... too bad I purchased it before just renting to check it out.

reviewText: My mom stuck this one in the VCR for me when I was a little toddler, and I insisted on watching it over and over again after the first viewing. But sometimes I wonder why I did, because honestly, most of it scared and disturbed me then.I hadn't seen it in at least 10 years when I checked it out at the library the other day to see how I felt about it.I'm telling you, don't hesitate to give it a shot; this is an excellent movie. There are so many meaningful things said and done, and the pacing, acting, animation, and music are all wonderful. I rather wish Lucas and Spielberg had made more animated films! This isn't a sugar-coated Disney movie, people; this is the real deal. It tells a tale of realistic characters learning how to accept each other and persevere until the end of their journey - which is happy, by the way; it just goes to show that a movie doesn't have to be dripping with sap for it to have a happy ending. Any incredible joy in the film is well-earned by its honest look at the bleak moments in life. This is a classic story that anyone can grow to love and appreciate.
summary: Love it more than I did as a little kid

reviewText: If you're only familiar with the awful awful awful direct-to-video sequels, then you are unprepared for the level of story-telling prowess on display here. This is animated  filmmaking in the best Disney tradition-- in other words, it's not really a  kids' movie.

reviewText: By far the best LBT movie. I own about 7 of the sequels. I still absolutly love this one! There is no annoying singing and the characters are innocent and adorable in this movie. The fact that they are serperated from their families and they find their way to them on their own just warms my heart. Many of the newer ones the kids run off on their own and have an adventure while their parents worry. Mother in this movie just makes me want to cry- she saves her only child by sacrificing herself and helps little foot find the way even in death. I love that they work together as friends to find their way to the great valley, get food, and defeat a sharptooth. It shows both love and acceptance of family and friends. It shows kids the great moral of seeing past someones apperence to make friends. LOVE this movie and I was so excited to buy it on DVD! Nothing bad to say.

reviewText: This is the original film that many of us grew up with. With such beauty and detail, how can anyone not like this film? James Horner performs his legendary compelling score and all of our favorite characters come to life in this classic. BUT, the DVD unfortunatley isn't up to par with those of us who are old enough to cross the street. Universal I guess has decided that this DVD will sell better if it's promoted directly toward kids and not fans. It's really a shame. It's like Disc 2 of Finding Nemo except you have to pay full price. It should have been done more like Finding Nemo and feature 1:85:1 Animorphic Widescreen, 5.1 Dolby Surround and 2 Channel Surround, audio commentary by director Don Bluth, and producers Steven Speilburg and George Lucas, and a documentary on Disc one. Disc two should be the DVD that they're trying to sell you now. It's deffinetly worth getting anyway, but still, it's a shame.
summary: What can I say, it's a classic. NOW STOP MAKING SEQUALS!!!!

reviewText: This is a masterpiece in my opinion. It is very sad indeed that the work is not in widescreen. However, even in fullscreen format, the light and shade in this movie... both in the art, and in the drama... is superb.The absence of songs is not a problem; children have more power of discernment than they are given credit for, and if the sequels ( which I also love) had no songs, and concentrated on the story more directly, then they would appeal more to Adults as well as children.This first film laid a high production value that the studio has failed to stick to, or even surpass.I suspect that we have either wacko conservative parents, or some biased screen testing to thank for the sequels that fail to live up to the quality of the first film.Don't get me wrong, I love the sequels enough to have bought everyone I have been aware of, and to date, I think I have missed only 2-3.I would not class this film as either an Adult or a child's film; simply put, a good film is a good film, and Don Bluth does a great job.The songs in the sequels are clearly for cross-merchandising... which I don't deny is a legitimate sales point for the studio. However, it does denigrate the memory of the first beautiful film; if they could release the film in its widescreen format, I suspect it would sell like the proverbial hot-cakes.And, as moving as the first film is, I also find many of the sequels quite emotionally charged, but then I tend to approach these film as a child would view them ... they touch the heart, and this first film does that on many levels.
summary: Beautiful Art by Don Bluth and Co

reviewText: I am a big fan of Don Bluth, but I truly think this is his greatest work. The soundtrack is among the best I've ever heard in my existence, and the animation is, of course, top notch. The storyline is unique, with engaging characters that possess a delightfully innocent feel to their entirety. Every time I need a break from the world, I come back and watch this movie. This was my favorite movie growing up, and it continues to be one I hold very dear to my heart.

reviewText: so this dvd is in pretty good condition, meaning the film was transferred to disc decently. i wouldn't call this dvd quality, but its just under dvd quality. in the beginning of the film it starts of a little grainy and blurry, but slightly, it than clears up pretty nicely once you see the dinosaurs. so dont get scared when the first 30 seconds or so are a lil off. it is a real old film and to my knowledge it wasn't digitally remastered. But i believe they used a really well kept film master, so in the end its a step up from our old VHS tapes of this movie. The sound comes in very nicely, there is english audio, spanish and french audio as well, theres also english for hard of hearing and french and spanish subtitles. I wish they had included the original theatrical trailer for this film but thats ok, the special features i haven't seen and really aren't the reason we are buying this classic film. i had this vhs tape back when i was 5, and am now 30 and just seeing little foot yawn just before going to sleep on his mothers back gave me such a nostalgic feeling and happiness. i'm glad i got to own this once again after all these years, decades even.so for those saying the video quality is horrible, please ignore them. yes, the film is old, but its been kept pretty well over the years, i am satisfied with the quality of the film. if anything its like a perfect vhs tape quality film.**UPDATE**i saw the entire film the other night, and i have to say the quality really held up. I assume they must of used a VHS tape master. It held up great, even on my 42" LED TV. there were no errors of any kind, video or audio. everything was great. Looking back at the film, it seems there may have been a couple of scenes that just didnt make it to the theatrical version. I have no proof of this, but there are a couple of scenes in the middle of the movie that point out that there was prolly an idea to make the scene longer but for whatever reason either took it out or it never came to pass. but it was still a great movie from beginning to end. i had forgotten diana ross sung the ending credits. the special features arent really all that for the adult buyer. they are lil kids games. one such feature shows how to navigate a remote controller for the youngin's out there. this is a great purchase, ignore those idiotic buyers that are hating on it for not being in widescreen. HELLO this movie was released WELL before widescreen was even popular and as such was made for 4:3 screens. the colors are good in this dvd.

reviewText: "The Land Before Time" is another animated movie that people should see. Don Bluth has almost always picked the right unknown actors to do the voices in his movies. Here, Gabriel Damon {Littlefoot}, Candice  Hutson {Cera}, and Judith Barsi {Ducky} are no exceptions. They all voiced  their roles with unique talent. They gave humor, emotion, and great charm  to their characters. Perhaps the greatest wonder and beauty of this movie  is the music by James Horner. It is considered by many people to be one of  his best scores. George Lucas and Steven Spielberg produced this movie, and  they are the reasons for you to see this movie. Four powerful names in  Hollywood-Lucas, Spielberg, Horner, and Bluth-and you have got a very good  movie.
summary: One of Don Bluth's few best movies

reviewText: THERE WAS THE LAND BEFORE TIME. The only reason any of us even paid attention to Jurassic Park was because this movie opened our eyes to the epic badassery of Sharptooth. What human with a heart wouldn't love this tale of adventure, reconciliation, teamwork, and all the good things in life? OH. And while the generation before us was still trying to figure out how to not be racist, we learned that lesson because The Land Before Time taught us that longnecks and three horns CAN play together! And they can kick Sharptooth's BUTT.

reviewText: Land Before Time starts of with a mother, grandpa, and grandma dinosaur waiting for their egg to hatch. When it does hatch, they're really excited. They then name it Littlefoot. But later on, Littlefoot's mother is killed by a dinosaur and then has to live with his grandma and grandpa. But, their valley is running low on food. So Littlefoot sets off on a journey to find a new valley with food. On the way, he meets Cera, Ducky, Petrie, and Spike. This is one of the best movies you'll ever want to see with your kids. This is truly a kids classic.
